title: 109_s432
content:
The "Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Act of 2005" establishes an Office within the National Science Foundation to support eligible institutions in providing instruction in digital and wireless network technologies. This includes grants, contracts, and agreements to strengthen national digital and wireless infrastructure. An eligible institution can use funding from the Act to acquire equipment, provide educational services in STEM fields, offer teacher training in technology, and collaborate on technology education projects with education agencies. The Act allows eligible institutions to receive funding for professional development, capacity-building technical assistance, fostering the use of information communications technology, and developing proposals for technology education. To develop proposals and strategic plans for information technology investments under this Act. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCEDURE. To be eligible for funding under this Act, institutions must submit an application to the Director, who will establish a procedure for review with input from an advisory council. The advisory council for the program includes representatives from various organizations to ensure diversity and expertise. Program review criteria consider demonstrated need and diversity among institutions. Eligible institutions must provide relevant data to the Office when receiving funding. The Director will convene an annual meeting for eligible institutions to foster collaboration, capacity-building, and disseminate information generated from the meetings. SEC. 5 of the Act requires eligible institutions to provide non-Federal contributions equal to 25% of the grant amount awarded by the Director, or $500,000, whichever is less. The matching requirement may be waived for institutions with no endowment or an endowment valued below $50,000,000. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS.

An eligible institution receiving a grant over $2,500,000 cannot receive another grant until all other eligible institutions have been awarded. Grants must be administered by the eligible institution, even for consortium projects.

SEC. 7. ANNUAL REPORT AND EVALUATION. Each institution receiving a grant must provide an annual report on its use of the funding. The Director evaluates the program every 2 years based on these reports, assessing the impact on students, faculty, and staff. A report is then submitted to Congress. The Director evaluates the program every 2 years based on annual reports from grant-receiving institutions. A report with recommendations on the need for Federal support is submitted to Congress. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible institution" refers to historically Black colleges or universities, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribally controlled colleges or universities, Alaska Native-serving institutions, and Native Hawaiian-serving institutions. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Science Foundation. The term "minority business" includes HUBZone small business concerns as defined in the Small Business Act. Authorization of appropriations of $250,000,000 for the National Science Foundation for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 to carry out the digital and wireless network technology program.
